Review: A Private War

26/02/2019

James Hudson reviews the film that is an insightful portrait of an unrelenting war correspondent

Image by

By James Bithell


7/10

Director: Matthew Heinemann

Running time: 1h10min

Rating:15

Starring: Rosamund Pike, Jamie Dornan, Tom Hollander, Stanley Tucci

The brilliant Sunday Times war correspondent Marie Colvin is the subject of Mathew Heinemannâ€™s latest film, A Private War, which investigates the story behind the stories, and the personal price she paid in uncovering them. It is an excellent portrait of an extraordinary woman and is nuanced enough to effectively dissociate the public person from the private. Based on a Vanity Fair article, A Private War follows Colvinâ€™s biggest articles; beginning in Sri Lanka, where an RPG attack results in blindness in one eye, the source of the trademark eyepatch, we then follow Colvin into Fallujah Iraq, where a mass grave is uncovered, a harrowing watch as family members weep while skulls are being extricated by a JCB digger.

The narrative is a dual one, the seemingly fearless Colvin we see in warzones is harshly juxtaposed to the PTSD-suffering, alcoholic Marie in London. The scenes in London are perhaps the most revealing, laying bare the consequences and private struggle of a woman who is otherwise publicly revered.  The portrayal of Marieâ€™s struggle with her unflinching drive to uncover the truth while struggling with her PTSD is the most impactful motif in the film; recurring nightmares and nervous breakdowns blend with the stubbornness of a tireless woman who is compelled to seek the truth. A line that captures Marieâ€™s personal cost is from her photographer, Paul Conroy (Jamie Dornan) who reminds her, â€œyouâ€™ve seen more war than most soldiersâ€. It is only back in London, surrounded by the glitz and sheen of parties and award ceremonies, where the horrors of what she has witnessed truly catch-up to her.

That does not take away from the brutality of the war zones, particularly the final 30-minutes of the film in Homs, Syria which are indistinguishable from documentary. In a scene where Marie is interviewing civilians seeking shelter in a ruined, cramped household, those she is talking to are non-professional actors who share the experience of their characters; it serves as a harsh reminder of the immediacy and reality of the conflict in Syria.

Another scene in the besieged city shows the pain of parents who witness their sonâ€™s death before their eyes. Heinemannâ€™s ability to capture the chaos and distress in Homs so accurately, and Colvinâ€™s mental state in them, is perhaps testament to his previous films: Cartel Land and City of ghosts, the latter following a group of Syrian activists fighting ISIS; perhaps why Homs is shot in such an authentic style; a violent energy of grit, blood, and metal. Heinemannâ€™s first-hand experience has served the film well, bringing to the surface the chaos and suffering of conflict, especially one as horrendous Syria.

Nevertheless, the filmâ€™s strength rests on Rosamund Pikeâ€™s performance as Marie; brilliantly capturing her internal struggle. Pike manages to portray the characteristic Brooklyn drawl and sardonic wit as well as Colvinâ€™s physical idiosyncrasies, even the change in the way she holds her head following the RPG attack in Sri Lanka. Pike deftly handles the shift between the restless drive of the war reporter and the jittery, distressed alcoholic who is haunted by the grotesque imagery of war.

A Private War is an excellent film; an adequately nuanced portrayal of a woman who should be remembered for what she has achieved, and the personal cost of uncovering the horrors of war.
